content: The "Protect and Preserve International Cultural Property Act" defines cultural property as outlined in the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict. The appropriate congressional committees are specified as the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate. SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND STATEMENT OF POLICY. Congress finds that protecting international cultural property is crucial for US cultural diplomacy, demonstrating respect for other cultures and the shared heritage of humanity. This protection is necessary due to the loss, damage, and destruction of cultural property caused by various threats such as political instability, armed conflict, and natural disasters. Recent events in Egypt, including political instability, have resulted in the ransacking of museums and the irreversible destruction of ancient artifacts, leaving significant gaps in the historical record of the ancient Egyptian civilization. Recent political instability in Egypt, Iraq, and Syria has led to the destruction and looting of museums, resulting in the loss of countless ancient artifacts. This includes approximately 15,000 items from the Iraq Museum in Baghdad, such as ancient amulets, sculptures, ivories, and cylinder seals. The ongoing civil war in Syria has also caused damage to medieval cities and UNESCO World Heritage sites. In Syria, ongoing civil war has led to shelling of medieval cities, damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and looting of museums and archaeological sites. ISIS/ISIL in Iraq and Syria destroyed cultural sites and artifacts, like the Tomb of Jonah, to eradicate ethnic identities. In Iraq and Syria, ISIS/ISIL destroyed cultural sites and artifacts, including the Tomb of Jonah, to eradicate ethnic and religious minorities. In Mali, Ansar Dine destroyed tombs and shrines in Timbuktu, a historic center for trade and Islam. In Mali, the Al-Qaeda affiliated group Ansar Dine destroyed tombs and shrines in Timbuktu, threatening ancient manuscripts. In Afghanistan, the Taliban destroyed the Bamiyan Buddhas, leading to global condemnation. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge seized control. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge systematically destroyed Buddhist temples, statues, and literature, as well as mosques and Catholic churches. In China, many antiques were destroyed during the Cultural Revolution, prompting current efforts to rebuild. In China, the Cultural Revolution led to the destruction of many antiques and parts of old Beijing. Chinese authorities are now working to rebuild lost architectural heritage. In Haiti, the 2010 earthquake destroyed important art, artifacts, and archives, as well as partially damaging the 17th century city of Jacmel. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami caused massive loss of life and damaged libraries, archives, and UNESCO World Heritage sites in eleven countries. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami caused massive loss of life and damaged or destroyed cultural properties such as libraries, archives, and UNESCO World Heritage Sites in eleven countries, including Mahabalipuram in India, the Sun Temple of Koranak, and the Old Town of Galle in Sri Lanka. This destruction represents an irreparable loss of humanity's cultural heritage. The United States Armed Forces have played a crucial role in preserving cultural property since 1943 when President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas. This Commission formed the Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) to provide expert advice on protecting cultural property. The American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas formed the Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) teams, known as the "Monuments Men," who secured and returned art stolen by the Nazis during World War II. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was founded. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was founded in 2006 to support the implementation of the 1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict and to coordinate with the United States military and other organizations in preserving international cultural property threatened by various disasters. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was established in 2006 to aid in safeguarding international cultural property at risk from political instability, armed conflict, or natural disasters. The United States is committed to protecting cultural property in accordance with the 1954 Hague Convention. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was established in 2006 to protect international cultural property during conflicts and disasters. The United States is obligated to safeguard cultural property under the 1954 Hague Convention and prevent the importation of pillaged or stolen artifacts. Laws and regulations, including import restrictions, are in place to support these efforts. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was established in 2006 to protect cultural property during conflicts and disasters. Laws and regulations, including import restrictions, are in place to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property. SEC. 4. WHITE HOUSE COORDINATOR FOR INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY PROTECTION. The President appoints a White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection to coordinate efforts among federal agencies and submit annual reports to congressional committees. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection, appointed by the President, must submit an annual report to congressional committees on interagency efforts to protect international cultural property. This includes providing policy recommendations, resolving interagency differences, and collaborating with various domestic and international actors. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection collaborates with various domestic and international actors to promote and protect international cultural property. SEC. 5. INFORMATION ON ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY. The Secretary of State must provide information to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities related to the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict. The Department has implemented procedures to safeguard international cultural property at risk from conflict or disasters and has taken actions to protect such property in conflicts involving the United States. Additionally, the Department has also taken steps to protect international cultural property in accordance with various cultural property protection statutes, international agreements, and policies. The United States has implemented procedures to protect international cultural property at risk from conflict or disasters. The Department has also taken actions to safeguard such property in conflicts involving the United States. Additionally, USAID is required to provide information on its efforts to protect international cultural property, including coordination with other entities. The USAID Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection provides information on efforts to protect cultural property at risk from various threats, including political unrest and natural disasters. The Department of Defense also submits information on its efforts to protect international cultural property. The Secretary of Defense submits information to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on Department of Defense activities to protect international cultural property, including efforts under the Hague Convention and other agreements. The Department of Justice, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, submits information on directives, policies, and actions taken to protect international cultural property at risk of destruction. This includes efforts to avoid damage to cultural property during construction activities abroad. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, submits information to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on Department of Justice efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities related to statutes and international agreements. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, provides information to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on Department of Justice efforts to safeguard international cultural property, including using statutes and regulations in criminal actions to prevent trafficking and smuggling. The Department of Justice works to interdict trafficking in stolen and smuggled cultural property, including investigating transnational organized crime. They also take actions to ensure consistent and effective application of law in cases related to international cultural property. Authorization for federal agencies to engage in international cultural property protection activities with the Smithsonian Institution is granted under Section 6 of the Act. The Act authorizes federal agencies to partner with the Smithsonian Institution for international cultural property protection activities, allowing them to temporarily utilize Smithsonian personnel for this purpose. The Act authorizes federal agencies to partner with the Smithsonian Institution for international cultural property protection activities, allowing them to utilize Smithsonian personnel for this purpose and cover their salaries and expenses. The Secretary of State is authorized to make grants for international cultural property protection activities in at-risk areas. Additionally, emergency protection for Syrian cultural property is addressed. The President will apply import restrictions to archaeological and ethnological material of Syria as if Syria were a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act. These restrictions will take effect within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. Import restrictions will be applied to archaeological and ethnological material of Syria, treating Syria as a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act. The term "archaeological or ethnological material of Syria" refers to cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria after August 18, 2011. The restrictions will be effective within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. The term "State Party" in the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act refers to cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria after August 18, 2011.
